identificationModule.briefTitle: Obesity and Asthma: Nutrigenetic Response to Omega-3 Fatty Acids
identificationModule.officialTitle: Obesity & Asthma: Nutrigenetic Response to Omega-3 Fatty Acids

collaborators.name: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)

descriptionModule.briefSummary: This project will assess the effectiveness of omega-3 fatty acid supplementation in controlling asthma symptoms among obese asthmatics, and will assess if a person's genes influence response to treatment (personalized medicine). This project may improve our ability to treat asthma and our understanding of the link between obesity and asthma.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: Obesity increases the risk for asthma diagnosis in children and adults. With obesity on the rise, a better understanding of this association may become critically important to public health. We will determine the impact of fish oil-derived Eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and Docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) on asthma control among obese asthmatics. These omega-3 fatty acids have been shown to: reduce inflammation important to asthma and improve asthma outcomes in an inconsistent manner across previous smaller studies - results that are consistent with a pharmacogenetic influence. There exists evidence that omega-3 fatty acid response displays a pharmacogenetic response related to ALOX5 genotype. Preliminary data suggests that obese individuals are at greater risk for possessing this same ALOX5 variant and thus obese asthmatics may be more responsive to fish oil. We will determine (in a sub-aim) if there exists an ALOX5 genotype-related response effect with fish oil. This will be the largest clinical trial of omega-3 fatty acid for the treatment of asthma, and the first applying pharmacogenetic/nutrigenetic analysis.

armGroups.label: omega-3 fatty acids
interventionNames: Dietary Supplement: omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids

armGroups.label: control
armGroups.description: Soybean oil: 3 matched softgel caps twice daily

interventions.name: omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids
interventions.description: ProEPA Xtra 1000mg softgels: 3 softgels twice daily

interventions.name: Omega-3 Fatty Acid
interventions.description: Soybean oil: 3(age 12-25) matched softgel caps twice daily

primaryOutcomes.description: The ACQ ranges from 0 to 6 (higher values indicate worse asthma control). A score greater than 1.25 in children is considered poor asthma control, and a change of 0.4 or greater is considered clinical meaningful.

secondaryOutcomes.description: Ratio of total omega-3 to total omega-6 polyunsaturated fatty acids from granulocytes in peripheral blood
Ratio of total omega-3 to total omega-6 polyunsaturated fatty acids from monocytes in peripheral blood
The asthma control test assesses patient reported symptoms from the prior month and has a range from 5 to 25 with a higher score suggesting better asthma control.
Leukotriene E4 obtained from urine was measured using liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry.
Forced expiratory volume in 1 second is a validated spirometry measure.

Exacerbations of asthma were defined by the need for urgent medical care (emergency room or urgent care clinic) or systemic corticosteroids to avoid severe worsening of asthma determined by study physician or local provider
Phone contact was defined as an urgent or unscheduled phone contact to a medical provider for asthma

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* age 12-25
* BMI \> 25 (age 18-25) or BMI%\>85th (age 12-17) (BMI Liberalized)
* Physician diagnosis of persistent asthma
* Lung function responsiveness by bronchodilator reversibility or bronchoprovocation testing

Exclusion Criteria:

* pregnancy
* currently taking LTRA for asthma control
* other serious chronic medical condition
* bleeding diathesis

overallOfficials.name: Jason E. Lang, M.D.
overallOfficials.affiliation: Duke Children's Hospital and Health Center

locations.facility: University of South Florida, Morsani College of Medicine

references.citation: Lang JE, Mougey EB, Hossain MJ, Livingston F, Balagopal PB, Langdon S, Lima JJ. Fish Oil Supplementation in Overweight/Obese Patients with Uncontrolled Asthma. A Randomized Trial. Ann Am Thorac Soc. 2019 May;16(5):554-562. doi: 10.1513/AnnalsATS.201807-446OC.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: 30 were excluded due to medical history and 15 was lost to follow-up during run-in.

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: Over the course of the study post randomization (24 weeks)
adverseEventsModule.description: Our adverse event and serious adverse event did not differ from the definitions outlined in clinicaltrials.gov.

seriousEvents.notes: Hospitalized for asthma exacerbation; respiratory distress

otherEvents.notes: Painful sensation in any part of the head
Salivary Glands are not making enough saliva in the mouth
Feeling of queasiness or wooziness or need to vomit
Intestinal organs are being stretched or distended
Liquid form of feces discharged from the bowels
Difficulty emptying the bowels; harden feces
Accumulation of gas in the stomach
Infection of the upper respiratory system
Pain and/or inflammation of the throat
Inflamed cavities around the nasal passages
